contentrichtext.text: In [[social philosophy]], '''objectification''' means treating a person as a thing, without regard to their [[dignity]]. According to the philosopher [[Martha Nussbaum]], a person is objectified if they are treated:<ref>[[Martha C. Nussbaum]], [http://www.jstor.org/pss/2961930 “Objectification”], ''[[Philosophy and Public Affairs]]'', 24 (4), pp. 279–83. {{OCLC|484757897}}</ref> *as a tool for another's purposes (instrumentality); *as if lacking in [[Agency (philosophy)|agency]] or [[self-determination]] (denial of [[autonomy]], [[inertness]]); *as if owned by another ([[ownership]]); *as if interchangeable ([[fungibility]]); *as if permissible to damage or destroy ([[Violence|violability]]); *as if there is no need for concern for their feelings and experiences (denial of [[subjectivity]]). ==See also== * [[Sexual objectification]] * [[Dehumanization]] ==External links== {{Wiktionary|objectification}} {{Wiktionary|objectify}} *{{Library resources about}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Social psychology]] [[Category:Feminist theory]] [[Category:Descriptive technique]] [[Category:Article Feedback 5]] {{philosophy-stub}}
